Violation_Type: Residency requirement violation under citizenship application
Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge correctly applied the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Chang was absent from Canada for 875 days during the four-year period; maintained long-term connections to Canada but also significant ties to Taiwan
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court found the citizenship judge's decision unreasonable
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the citizenship judgeâ€™s decision
Defendant_Behavior: Extended absences from Canada; maintained dual life between Canada and Taiwan
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet physical residency requirement despite temporary absence allowances
Legal_Standard: Residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Assessment_Factor: Duration and pattern of absences, strength of residential ties to Canada vs. foreign country
Procedural_Issue: Standard of review in administrative decisions regarding citizenship
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged, but evidence of ties evaluated
Evidence_Used: Record of absences (875 days), evidence of connections to Canada and Taiwan
Application_Basis: Requirement to be physically resident in Canada for at least 1,095 days within four years prior to application
Evidence_Assessed: Ties to Canada and Taiwan, duration of absences
Governing_Rule: Applicants must establish and maintain residency in Canada despite temporary absences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge failed to consider evidence of significant ties to Taiwan
Harm_Assessment: Risk of granting citizenship to individuals not meeting statutory residency requirements
Cause_Description: Chang's extensive absences and dual life pattern between Canada and Taiwan
Evidence_Handling: Federal Court found that relevant evidence of foreign ties was overlooked
Evidence_Issues: Incomplete assessment of residency by ignoring substantial ties to another country
Residency_Compliance: Not met due to excessive absences and lack of primary residence in Canada
Evidence_Assessment: Evaluation of residential ties and absence patterns
Decision_Rationale: The decision was unreasonable because it did not account for all relevant evidence regarding Chang's ties to Taiwan
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to consider material evidence of foreign residency ties
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in administrative law review
